description: From Middle English ponnen, ponen, punen, from Old English punian, pūnian (“to pound, beat, bray, bruise, crush, grind”), from Proto-Germanic *punōną (“to break to pieces, pulverize”). See pound. As a kind of word play, from the notion of "beating" the words into place.

entries.meaning: A joke or type of wordplay in which similar definitions or sounds of two words or phrases, or different definitions of the same word, are deliberately confused.

verbs.description: pun (third-person singular simple present puns, present participle punning, simple past and past participle punned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To beat; strike with force; to ram; to pound, as in a mortar; reduce to powder, to pulverize.
(intransitive) To make or tell a pun; to make a play on words.
examples: We punned about the topic until all around us groaned.

description: From the McCune-Reischauer romanization of Korean 분 (bun), from Chinese 分 (“fen”).

entries.meaning: (Korean units of measure) Alternative form of bun: a Korean unit of length equivalent to about 0.3 cm.
